publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in ŠorčuqStadthöhleduring T III Š 79.12

sourceDesc.p: Transcription and references have been transferred from the "Text and Reference Database of the Tocharian A Language" (Gerd Carling Lund University) (funded by the Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and SCAS).
Transcription and translation are based on .

seg.seg: In der Meditation möge er nicht nachlässig sein.
He shall not be negligent in meditation.
whose self is reflecting, this stanza has been the Prātimokṣa under the Buddha Lord Kanakamuni ...
... 7. This stanza was the Prātimokṣa under the Buddha Kāśyapa ... (self-control concerning the body [is] good)
(good) [is] self-control (in talking), in thinking self-control [is] good, self-control [is] good in everything ...
... With the body one should do no evil either. ...
[Even if] scolded [himself], may he [in turn] never scold.
... by [the Buddhas] having a great nature; a Prātimokṣa has been presented and announced ...
Auf! [wtl. fangt an!] Geht hinaus [und] schließt euch der Lehre des Buddha an!
Come on! [lit. begin!] Go out [and] join the teaching of the Buddha!
He who in the discipline of the law will not be careless, who has taken away the cycle of birth, he will go to the end of sorrow.

div.p: Edition195-196; 74-77. Siegling's personal copy of p. 195 p. 196.

list.item: a1 ... study! ... a2 whose self is reflecting, this stanza has been the Prātimokṣa under the Buddha Lord Kanakamuni ... a3 ... 7. This stanza was the Prātimokṣa under the Buddha Kāśyapa ... (self-control concerning the body [is] good) a4 (good) [is] self-control (in talking), in thinking self-control [is] good, self-control [is] good in everything ... a5 ... With the body one should do no evil either. ... b1 ... insulted may one never insult ... b2 ... blamed by others b3 ... by [the Buddhas] having a great nature; a Prātimokṣa has been presented and announced ... b4 ... disciples of the Buddhas ... b6 He who in the discipline of the law will not be careless, who has taken away the cycle of birth, he will go to the end of sorrow.

a1 – – – – – : plyaskenaṃ ma(r yä)knāśśiträ : skam ri – – – – – – – – twaṃ āklye – – – – (śu)rāmäntu mā mäskaträ kāk(mä) – – – – – – – a2 – – – (yma)ssu āñmatsumäntāp (6) säs ṣlyok kanakamuni ptāñäktā prātimokäṣ : poñcäṃ omäskuneyis mā yāmlu(ne) – – – – – – a3 – – – – – – āṣtrone – : ptāñäkte enäṣlune 7 säs ṣlyok kāsyap ptāñäktā prātimokäṣ ṣeṣ : – – – – – – – – – a4 – – – – – – śkaṃ kroplune : pältsäkyo kroplune kāsu : kāsu pukyo kroplune : pukyo kāsu kākropu ṣāmaṃ – – – – – – – a5 /// āneñci kākropu : kapśiñño śkaṃ omäskeṃ mar yāmiṣ : tosäs krant lyalypurṣinās – – – – – – – a6 /// s· 9 (tiṃ) wu ṣlyokañ śākyamuni ptāñäktā malto prātimokäṣ tākenes äntā ne ś· – – – – – – – – b1 /// ci prātimokäṣ täpreṃ täpreṃ tsmāluneyaṃ kälk : kākṣiñu kāṣiññiträ marr o(n)t(aṃ) kākäṣ·· – – – – – – – – b2 /// sn(e) yäslurñe : māmäṃntuñcsaṃ śkaṃ tākiṣ skam wsok : mättak mar yāmiṣ ālu nāṅkunt – ·n· – – – – – – b3 – – – – – – s· : ptāñäktes tsraṣisā tsopats āñmatsumäñcsā : prātimokäṣ ṣaṣärpu ākṣiññu śkaṃ tsopa – – – – – b4 – – (ś)l(a) ynāñmuneyumäṣ ptāñäktañ : ptāñäktaśśi ākläṣlye śkaṃ k_uce ne : tṣaṃ śla ynāñmune nāṃtsuräṣ ā – – – – – – – b5 – k· – – kaknuṣ yomnāseñc k_uyalte täm mā yāmṣunt : posāc pälcas : pritwäs ptāñäkte enäṣluneyaṃ : ptäpsäs wlaluneṣiṃ|wlalune|(ṣiṃ) b6 (ratäk • kärw)āṣi waṣt mä«nt» ne oṅkaläm : 13 kus ne nu caṣ märkampalṣi enäṣluneyaṃ (sne) (y)korñe tāṣ : wawikuräṣ cmo – – – – –

Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a1 In der Meditation möge er nicht nachlässig sein. 177
b1 Gescholten möge er niemals schelten. 172
b5 Auf! [wtl. fangt an!] Geht hinaus [und] schließt euch der Lehre des Buddha an! 370


Middle of a1 supplemented to read āklye (pyāmt)[s](āc) by [[Carling, DThTA]]: 37 (TI)

first word of a2 restored to (yma)ssu in [[Carling, DThTA]]: 43 (TI)

b1 restoration to o(n)t(aṃ) towards the end of this line in [[Carling, DThTA]]: 152 (TI)

The end of a3 supplemented to read [k](apśiñño kroplune kāsu), continued in line a4, which is supplemented to (kāsu rake-yo) śkaṃ kro[p]lune in [[Carling, DThTA]]: 153 (TI)


Translation [[Ogihara 2009]]: 275-276:
a1 In the meditation one should not be negligent. Learn always ... of the sageness. The grieves do not exist for the master (who) ... ///
a2 /// for the one who is always himself mindful. 6 This stanza was the Prātimokṣa under the Buddha Kanakamuni. Not doing any evil. (Of a good deed) ... ///
a3 /// the purity of the own mind. It is the doctrine of Buddha. 7 This stanza was the Prātimokṣa under the Buddha Kāśyapa.
a4 The concentration by the body is good. The concentration by the speech is also good. The concentration by the thought is also good. The concentration by everything is also good. The monk, well concentrated in everything,
a5 will be freed from every pain. 8 /// /// Concentrated carefully by the speech, one should not do the evil by the body. These paths of the good deed ///
a6 /// taught. 9 These two stanzas were the foremost Prātimokṣa under the Buddha Śākyamuni. When (the Śākyamuni Buddha) ///
b1 /// [immortality], as much, as much the Prātimokṣa went into growing. Even if one is scold, one should not scold, [wounded] ///
b2 /// one should be without hostility. And one should be always pure to those who bear the malice. One should not do himself the thing to be reproached by others. 10
b3 /// Under the Buddhas, under the powerful ones, under the noble-hearted ones, and under a great (sage), the Prātimokṣa has been explained and taught (11).
b4 /// the Buddhas are with respect about it, and those who are the pupils of the Buddhas. After having become with respect about it, being with respect to each other,
b5 having been provided with shame (and) modesty, then they attain certainly the uncreated one. Begin! Leave! Be linked with the instruction of Buddha! Destroy the army
b6 of the death as the elephant destroys the house of reeds. 13 Who will be careful about the teaching of this law, having removed the cycle of the births, he will go to the end of the pains. 14

a1 – – – – – [:] plyaskenaṃ «ma» – k[n]āśś[it]_r_a [:] sk[a_m\] ri – – – – – – – – tw[aṃ] āklye – – – – – rā_m_antu mā _m_askat_r_a kā_k – – – – – – – – a2 – – – – ssu āñ[m]atsu[_m]_antā[_p] – _s_a_s\ ṣlyo_k\ kanakamuni [ptā]ñäktā prātimo_k_a_ṣ\ : poñcäṃ o_m_askuneyis mā yāmlu – – – – – – – a3 – – – – – – [āṣtrone] – : ptāñäkte enäṣlune 7 _s_a_s\ ṣlyo_k\ kāsya_p\ ptāñäktā prātimo_k_a_ṣ\ ṣe_ṣ\ : – – – – – – – – – a4 – – – – – – śkaṃ kro[p]lune : _p_a_lt_s_akyo kroplune [k]āsu : kāsu pukyo kroplune : pukyo kāsu kākropu ṣāmaṃ – – – – – – – a5 /// āneñci kākropu : kapśiñño śkaṃ o_m_askeṃ mar yāmi_ṣ\ : to_s_a_s\ kran_t\ lyalypurṣinā[_s\] – – – – – – – a6 /// s· 9 – [wu] ṣlyokañä\ śākyamuni ptāñäktā malto prātimo_k_a_ṣ\ tāken[e]_s\ äntā ne ś· – – – – – – – – b1 /// ci prātimo_k_a_ṣ\ _t_apreṃ _t_apreṃ tsmāluneyaṃ _k_a_l_k\ : kākṣiñu kāṣiññit_r_a ma[rr] o·t· kā_k_aṣ·· – – – – – – – – b2 /// sn· yäslurñe : mā_m_aṃntuñcsaṃ śkaṃ tāki_ṣ\ ska_m\ wso_k\ : _m_atta_k\ mar yāmi_ṣ\ ālu nāṅku[n_t\] – ·n· – – – – – – b3 – – – – – – s· : ptāñäkte_s\ tsraṣisā tsopat_s\ āñmatsu_m_añcsā : prātimo_k_a_ṣ\ ṣa_ṣ_arpu ākṣiññu śkaṃ tsopa – – – – – b4 – – ·l· [ynā]ñmuneyu_m_a_ṣ\ ptāñäktañä\ : ptāñäktaśśi ā_k_l_aṣlye śkaṃ k_uce ne : tṣaṃ śla ynāñmune nāṃtsu_r_a_ṣ\ ā – – – – – – – b5 – k· – – [ka]knu_ṣ\ yomnāseñcä\ k_uyalte _t_a_m\ mā yāmṣun_t\ : posā[cä\] _p_a_lca_s\ : pritwä«_s\» ptāñäkte enäṣluneyaṃ : _p_t_a_p_s_a_s\ wlalu[ne] b6 – ·āṣi wa_ṣ_t\ _m_a ne oṅka_l_a_m\ : 10-3 kus ne nu ca_ṣ\ _m_arka[mpa]lṣi enäṣlune[yaṃ] – ·k[o]rñe tā_ṣ\ : wawiku_r_a_ṣ\ cmo – – – – –

div.p: Middle of supplemented to read āklye (pyāmt)[s](āc) by <citedRange>37</citedRange></bibl> (TI)</p><p>first word of <ref type="ms" target="__a2"/> restored to <hi>(yma)ssu</hi> in <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>43</citedRange></bibl> (TI)</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__b1"/> restoration to <hi>o(n)t(aṃ)</hi> towards the end of this line in <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>152</citedRange></bibl> (TI)</p><p>The end of <ref type="ms" target="__a3"/> supplemented to read <hi>[k](apśiñño kroplune kāsu)</hi>, continued in line a4, which is supplemented to <hi>(kāsu rake-yo) śkaṃ kro[p]lune</hi> in <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>153</citedRange></bibl> (TI)</p><p>Translation <bibl><title corresp="ref:ogihara2009"/><citedRange>275-276</citedRange></bibl>: a1 In the meditation one should not be negligent. Learn always ... of the sageness. The grieves do not exist for the master (who) ... /// a2 /// for the one who is always himself mindful. 6 This stanza was the Prātimokṣa under the Buddha Kanakamuni. Not doing any evil. (Of a good deed) ... /// a3 /// the purity of the own mind. It is the doctrine of Buddha. 7 This stanza was the Prātimokṣa under the Buddha Kāśyapa. a4 The concentration by the body is good. The concentration by the speech is also good. The concentration by the thought is also good. The concentration by everything is also good. The monk, well concentrated in everything, a5 will be freed from every pain. 8 /// /// Concentrated carefully by the speech, one should not do the evil by the body. These paths of the good deed /// a6 /// taught. 9 These two stanzas were the foremost Prātimokṣa under the Buddha Śākyamuni. When (the Śākyamuni Buddha) /// b1 /// [immortality], as much, as much the Prātimokṣa went into growing. Even if one is scold, one should not scold, [wounded] /// b2 /// one should be without hostility. And one should be always pure to those who bear the malice. One should not do himself the thing to be reproached by others. 10 b3 /// Under the Buddhas, under the powerful ones, under the noble-hearted ones, and under a great (sage), the Prātimokṣa has been explained and taught (11). b4 /// the Buddhas are with respect about it, and those who are the pupils of the Buddhas. After having become with respect about it, being with respect to each other, b5 having been provided with shame (and) modesty, then they attain certainly the uncreated one. Begin! Leave! Be linked with the instruction of Buddha! Destroy the army b6 of the death as the elephant destroys the house of reeds. 13 Who will be careful about the teaching of this law, having removed the cycle of the births, he will go to the end of the pains. 14</p></project_comment>
